BIBREF33.title: Conclusion: RIC alloSCT with intensifi ed fl udarabine regimen is associated with reduced early TRM and favourable OS and PFS in pts with advanced lymphoid malignancies non eligible for myeloablative regimens. Disease status and chronic GVHD seems to have a positive impact on OS. Efforts may be directed to identify patients who achieved response to previous regimens prior to move to RIC alloSCT. Background: In this retrospective analysis, we summarized our experience with RIC and MC after the fi rst HCT in patients (pts) with AML and CML in order to compare the longer-term outcome of these treatment procedures. Methods: 70 pts were transplanted during the 1998-2007 using PBSC from matched sibling donors. The RIC (37 pts) and MC (33 pts) groups were balanced regarding the diagnosis and disease stage. The RIC patients, however, signifi cantly differed from MC patients in median age (51 y vs. 35 y). The RIC consisted of fl udarabine (30 mg/m2/d; 5 days), busulfan (total dose 8-12 mg/kg), and ATG Fresenius (10 mg/kg/d; 4 days), posttransplant immunosuppression was mostly cyclosporine alone. The conventional regimen was busulfan (total dose 14-16 mg/ kg) + cyclophosphamide (120 mg/kg) followed by post-transplant cyclosporine and methotrexate. Results: The RIC vs. MC group had a median follow up 1561 (4,3 y) vs. 1898 days (5,2y), respectively. None or mild RRT was more frequent and severe RRT less frequent in RIC group in comparison with MC group (Tab 1). Eleven percent and 22% of patients in the RIC and MC group did not achieve a complete chimerism, usually for early disease progression. Median time to achievement a complete chimerism was 166 vs.108 days for RIC and MC, respectively. Concerning GvHD, the incidence and severity was less in the RIC group (Tab. 1). Nine/15 AML pts (60%) in RIC group relapsed and 6 of them died (40%), whereas 8/16 AML pts (50%) relapsed and 7 of them died (46%) in MC group. Twenty/22 (91%) RIC CML pts were alive, all in molecular remission (MR), versus 14/17 (82%) CML living pts from MC group. Whereas only 1/17 CML pts (6%) relapsed in MC group, 10/22 CML pts (45%) in RIC group relapsed (4 pts once) and 10/10 achieved new MR after treatments (DLI, imatinib, dasatinib, retransplantation) and 2/10 of them died (1 for new progression and 1 for GVHD after DLI). Mortality from any cause was 24% vs. 36%, NRM was 5% vs. 15%, early TRM was 5% (for disease progression) vs. 15%, late TRM was 5% vs. 3% for RIC and MC patients, respectively. Conclusion: Allogeneic SCT after RIC conditioning using Flu-Bu-ATG ( Fresenius) is well tolerated, after this procedure, all CML pts achieved CMR, however, quite frequent interventions for molecular relapses are required than conventional myeloablative regimen. This regimen can completely replace standard conditioning in AML pts. This work was supported by grant IGA MZ CR NS9683-4

FIGREF57.text: P663Adverse impact of iron overload on transplant outcome G.Sucak, Z.A. Yegin, Z. Özkurt, Z. Aki, M. Yagci  Gazi University Faculty of Medicine (Ankara, TR)    Introduction: Iron overload(IO) is a well-recognized problem in patients undergoing hematopoietic stem cell transplantation(HSCT) for underlying hematologic malignancies. Pretransplant iron burden is a signifi cant contributor to transplant-related morbidity and mortality. This retrospective review is planned to assess the impact of pretransplant iron status on overall survival(OS) and transplant-related complications(TRC). Methods: The charts of 250 patients [M/F:162/88; median age 34(16-71)] who underwent HSCT[148 allogeneic (allo), 102 autologous (auto)] at Gazi University SCT Unit were retrospectively reviewed. Median follow-up was 315(1-1809) days. We evaluated the effect of IO, as measured by pretransplant serum iron, iron binding capacity, ferritin and transferrin saturation(TS) on survival, mortality and toxic-infectious complications. Results: Median pretransplant ferritin level was 576,2(2,1-26971)ng/ml [231,36

FIGREF62.text: P677Immune reconstitution more than one year after allogeneic haematopoietic stem cell transplantation S.Narayan, J. Adams, G. Lucas, J. Burthem, E. Tholouli,  H. Lenehan, J.A.L. Yin  Manchester Royal Infi rmary (Manchester, UK)    Duration of immune defi ciency post haemopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) is highly variable. We enumerated circulating natural killer cells & lymphocyte subsets post transplant in association with stem cell source, chronic graft versus host disease (cGVHD), conditioning and recipient age. We studied 63 patients more than one year post transplant. Peripheral blood samples were analysed using fl ow cytometry. The absolute counts of T & B lymphocytes, NK cells, CD4+ & CD8+ T cell subsets were determined. Results were correlated with graft, host & transplant related factors.

FIGREF88.text: P725The predictive value of [18f]fdg -pet/ct after autologous stem cell transplantationF. Sorà, N. Piccirillo, P. Chiusolo, L. Laurenti, M. Lavalle,  I. Innocenti, G. Ausoni, S. De Matteis, V. Rufi ni, G. Leone,  S. Sica  Catholic University of Rome (Rome, IT)    Autologous stem cell transplantation (ASCT) is a standard treatment for refractory or relapsed lymphoma. Defi ning response criteria based on conventional radiographic characteristics remains diffi cult because anatomical technique, as computed tomography (CT), cannot differentiate between active tumor and fi brosis. 18fl uorodeoxyglucose positron emission tomography ([18F]FDG-PET/CT), has been clinically accepted and widely use to optimize lymphoma restaging during and after chemotherapy. The aim of this study is to evaluate the role of [18F]FDG-PET/CT to detect residual disease or early relapse after ASCT in order to design treatment intensifi cation or complementary radiotherapy. From December 2004 to June 2008 we enrolled 49 patients (31 males and 18 females, median age: 50 years, range 15-66) affected by lymphoma (16 large B cell, 10 follicular, 8 mantle cell, 2 anaplastic CD30, 5 peripheral T cell, 2 other subtypes and 6 Hodgkin's lymphoma). Patients were homogeneously treated with salvage chemotherapy and received ASCT, respectively 27 patients in CR, 17 patients in PR, and 5 in SD/PD.

Jürgens (8) (1)St. Anna Children's Hospital (Vienna, AT); (2)Children's Cancer (Vienna, AT); (3)University College Hospital (London, UK); (4)Institut Gustave Roussy (Villejuif, FR); (5)University Children's Hospital Basel (Basel, CH); (6)CCLG Data Centre (Leicester, UK); (7)University of Amsterdam (Amsterdam, NL); (8)University Children's Hospital (Münster, DE) Purpose: To assess prognostic factors at diagnosis in prospectively treated patients with primary extra-pulmonary metastatic Ewing tumors (EPM-ET) of the EURO-E.W.I.N.G. 99 Study. Patients and Methods: From 1999 to 2005, 281 patients were enrolled. Median age was 16.2 years (0.4-49). Primary site was extremity in 84 patients and axial in 197 (115 pelvic sites), with a tumor volume >200ml in 171 patients. Treatment consisted of 6 VIDE cycles, one VAI/VAC cycle, local treatment (surgery and/or radiotherapy), and high-dose busulfan-melphalan followed by peripheral stem cell transplantation (HDT/SCT).

FIGREF133.text: (A.) autologous, (B.) fully matched-, (C.) mismatched-and (D.) haploidenticalallogeneic HSCT. Patients & Methods: Patients receiving HSCT in the Hadassah Hebrew University Medical Center over a 5-year period (April 2003-March 2008) were retrospectively reviewed for the occurrence of CMV infection and disease in relation to the 4 types of HSCT. Infection was defi ned by the presence of positive CMV antigenemia and/or real time PCR assays, and patients received preemptive antiviral treatment upon detection of CMV infection. Results: Of 634 patients who received HSCT during the study period, 276 (43.5%) developed CMV infection and 16 (2.5%) had evidence for CMV disease, with the vast majority of disease occurring among haploidentical HSCT recipients. The occurrence of CMV infection and disease by transplant type is presented in the table.

Fernández de Sevilla (1) (1)Institut Catalá d'Oncologia (Barcelona, ES); (2)Health Economics Unit, Schering-Plough España (Madrid, ES) Posaconazole (POSA) has shown to be superior to fl uconazole and/or itraconazole (ITRA) as antifungal prophylaxis in patients with prolonged neutropenia or GVHD. Here, we present our experience with POSA prophylaxis during the neutropenic phase post-allogeneic stem cell transplant (alloSCT). Forty three consecutive alloSCT recipients with no prior history of invasive fungal infection (IFI) received either POSA (n=27; 200mg/8h oral; from May 2007) or ITRA (ITRA; n=16; oral and/or iv; up to May 2007) for primary antifungal prophylaxis.

TABREF13.text: Goal: To explore characteristics and individual factors of OM in FLU/MEL patients. Methods: Prospective observation. FLU/MEL conditioning regimen (fl udarabine 30 mg/m² i.v. once daily for 4 days in total dose 120 mg/m², melphalan 140 mg/m² i.v. once daily on one day prior to transplantation). Amiphostine, palifermin and cryotherapy were not used for OM prevention. OM assessed by WHO grading 0-4. TABREF20.text: or 0.81 [p<0.0001], respectively). EBV detection in plasma was less sensitive than in WB or PBMC. Thus, correlations between plasma and WB or between plasma and PBMC were lower (plasma versus WB: r=0.57 [p<0.0001]; plasma versus PBMCw/o: r=0.51 [p<0.0001]; plasma versus PBMCw: r=0.50 [p<0.0001]). Conclusions:The three blood compartments (whole blood, PBMC and plasma) show different kinetics of their EBV DNA levels after allogeneic HSCT. Monitoring of EBV DNA levels in whole blood appears to be a valuable alternative to PBMC. Normalization of EBV DNA in PBMC towards an endogenous standard does not seem to provide additional information.

TABREF22.text: venous devices in haematologic malignancies and haematopoietic stem cell transplantation patients. A single-centre experience E. Carrillo Cruz, J. Falantes González, J. González Campos, M. Ruiz Seixas, A. Urbano Ispizua, I. Espigado Tocino Hospital Virgen del Rocio (Sevilla, ES) Background: Tunnelled central venous catheters (CVC) are routinely used in haematological patients. CVC include total implantable devices (ports) and Hickman catheter. Catheterrelated bloodstreams infection (CRBI) is reported approximately as 1.6 episodes per 1000 catheter days in tunneled CVC. Objectives: Prospectively analyse incidence, morbidity and mortality related to tunnelled CVC in hematologic malignancies and hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HSCT) patients. Patients and methods: From january 2008, 62 CVC were placed in 57 pts (ports devices, n=19 and Hickman, n=43). 35 pts planned for HSCT and 27 pts for intensive chemotherapy. Observation period included chemotherapy treatment, hospital admissions and as outpatien follow-up. Results: Infection episodes occured in 26 CVC (41,9%): 17 were local (16 in Hickman and 1 in ports) and 10 episodes of CRBI (3 in ports and 7 in Hickman) for a global systemic catheter-related infection of 16,1% (1,5 episodes of CRBI per 1000 catheter days: 1,15 per 1000 catheter days in ports and 1,7 in Hickman)

Results: Graft failure occurred in three patients in each group. Engraftment of neutrophils and platelets occurred at a median of 19 days (range 11-50) and 14 days (0-106) after HSCT with no difference between the two groups. The effect of transfusions and iron toxicity on non-relapse mortality in patients with untreated adult MDS treated with myeloablative alloSCT: a retrospective study of the MDS subcommittee of the Chronic Leukaemia Working Party of the EBMT L. Spinnewijn, A. van Biezen, R. Brand, J. Finke, U. Platzbecker, T. Ruutu, D. Beelen, R. Schwerdtfeger, Y. Floisand, R. Martino, D. Niederwieser, A. Atienza, K. Steinerova, N. Kröger, T. de Witte on behalf of the MDS subcommittee of the Chronic Leukaemia Working Party of the EBMT Background: Standard treatment for MDS includes blood product transfusions, in some cases followed by allogeneic stem cell transplantation (alloSCT) after a standard myeloablative regimen. This treatment approach leads to considerable treatment-related morbidity and non-relapse mortality (NRM) during the fi rst 6 months after treatment with alloSCT. This increased mortality of transfused patients can partly be attributed to increased iron toxicity, caused by frequent erythrocyte transfusions, release of toxic iron radicals by the intensive treatment itself and its associated ineffective hematopoiesis and some other less well defi ned processes. Most information about iron overload and chelation originates from non-MDS patients. Therefore this study aims to quantify the effects of iron overload in MDS patients. Methods: A retrospective analysis of data from the EBMT registry was carried out with an additional survey within EBMT centers, covering in total 206 adult MDS patients who were treated with alloSCT between 2000 and 2005. Only patients were included with alloSCT as their primary treatment, and who were classifi ed as MDS patients or as patients with MDS transformed to acute myeloid leukemia (sAML) at time of SCT. Results: 63 patients were categorized as refractory anaemia with or without ring sideroblasts (RA/RARS), 100 patients as RA with excess of blasts (RAEB), and 38 patients as RAEB in transformation (RAEB-t) or sAML. The estimated 3-years NRM, relapse rate (RR), relapse free survival (RFS) and overall survival (OS) for the whole group were 44%, 17%, 39% and 44%, respectively. Univariate analyses showed that RR, RFS and OS were signifi cantly infl uenced by disease classifi cation (p=0.02, p=0.004 and p=0.02). NRM was not infl uenced by disease stage (p=0.18). A low number of transfusions (<20) led to a decrease of the relapse risk (p=0.05). The other assessed variables, including age, donor type and the interval between diagnosis and SCT, had no signifi cant impact on all disease outcomes. The multivariate Cox-regression analyses showed again a signifi cant impact of disease classifi cation at SCT, but now for all endpoints, including NRM (p=0.04). An early SCT (interval between diagnose and disease < 6 months) correlated with an increased survival rate (p=0.04). Conclusion: These preliminary data show that disease stage has a signifi cant impact on outcome. More data are collected to quantify the impact of the number of transfusions and of iron toxicity.

back_matter.text: Allogeneic haematopoietic stem cell transplantation as front line therapy for patients with "de novo" or secondary myelodysplastic syndrome: a single-centre experience M. Sorio, R. Di Bella, A. Andreini, C. Tecchio, F. Frattini, G. Quaresmini, F. Randon, G. Ruggeri, A. Al-Kafaff, S. Ledro, D. de Sabata, F. Benedetti Bone Marrow Transplant Unit (Verona, IT) Introduction Myelodisplastic syndromes (MDS) are a heterogeneous group of hematologic malignancies with an elevated risk of developing acute myeloid leukemia. Conventional chemotherapy is unable to cure the disease. Allogeneic transplant is the only curative treatment, but very often it's not suitable because of age and comorbidities. Patients characteristics 47 consecutive pts with "de novo" and secondary MDS, including transformed acute myeloid leukemia (t-AML) were treated between 1993 and 2007. At the diagnosis, according to the FAB, the pts were classifi ed as: 14 RA, 12 RAEB, 18 RAEB-T, CMML 1, SAA 1. According to WHO the same patients resulted classifi ed as: 1 RA, 12 RCMD, 6 RAEB-1, 11 RAEB-2, 3 MDS-U and 1 CMML. Median age was 51 years (range 11-66), M/F 26/21. When enrolled in the transplant program, 23/47 pts had already developed an overt leukemia. The median time of transformation to AML was 4.6 months Seventeen/23 of these pts (74%) were treated with at least one course of conventional chemotherapy. Nevertheless a complete remission was reached in a minority of pts. The conditioning regimen consisted of FTBI (200 cGy x 6) + CTX or BUCy for 35 pts. Reduced Intensity Conditioning (RIT), including Thiotepa, Fludara, Cyclophosphamide, was chosen for 12 pts over 60 years or suffering comorbidities. The source of stem cells was identical sibling for 28 pts, unrelated donor for the remaining cases. Outcomes We observed 11/47 (23%) cases of transplant related mortality within 100 days (3 infections, 2 CNS bleeding, 2 Multi Organ Failure, 2 VOD, 2 acute GVHD), 8/11 cases in the group of pts treated with myeloablative regimens, and 3/11 in the RIT group. After day +100, relapse was the most important cause of death: 9 pts, 3 pts in RIC group and 6 in the group transplanted with conventional regimens, in most cases within 6 months. The overall incidence of acute GVHD of clinical grade >II, and the chronic GVHD, was 55% (26/47) and 26% (12/47), respectively. The overall survival (OS) was 47% (median follow-up 14 months). The sibling donor (28 cases) still seems the best source of stem cells: in fact, as compared with unrelated donor (18 cases), we obtained an OS of 53% and 33%, respectively. Conclusions Allogeneic HCT from a suitable HLA-matched donor is o good curative option for patients with MDS, including those with t-AML (about 50% of cured cases). Despite the elevated median age of these pts, an acceptable related mortality was observed.

back_matter.text: Role of co-morbidity score, age and disease status at transplant in predicting survival and non-relapse mortality in patients with MDS and leukaemia undergoing reduced-intensity conditioning transplantation S.W. Bokhari, L. Watson, E. Das-Gupta, J. Byrne, N. Russell Nottingham City Hospital (Nottingham, UK) Allogeneic stem cell transplantation is the favoured treatment for high risk leukemias and MDS, but its utlility is limited to younger fi tter patients. Reduced intensity conditioning (RIC) regimens have allowed older patients, often with co-morbidities, to undergo HSCT. The HCT-comorbidity index has been validated in predicting non-relapse mortality(NRM) in some studies comparing myeloablative versus RIC conditioning. Patients receiving RIC allografts are however very heterogenous as far as their co-morbidities are concerned and it is uncertain whether one can further delineate groups of RIC allograft recipients with signifi cantly different mortality and outcomes. This retrospective single centre study was done to assess the outcome of RIC transplants in patients with MDS and leukemia based on their co-morbidity scores in addition to other prognostic factors. 90 RIC allografts were performed between 2002 and 2008. Factors analysed in addition to HCT-comorbidity index were age of >60 years, disease status at transplant, CMV status, stem cell source and donor type(related/unrelated). The median age at transplant was 58.5 years(29-71.1) with a median follow-up of 23 months . The number of patients with scores 0-2 and ≥3 was 53 and 33 respectively(scores not available in 4). The commonest co-morbidity was moderate pulmonary function impairment. The overall survival(O.S) and NRM of the whole cohort was 51% and 28% at 2 years respectively. NRM of patients with HCT-CI of ≥3 was higher as compared to those with score 0-2 reaching statistical signifi cance both on uni-and multivariate analyses(p 0.02). Age >60 years was also a signifi cant factor on multivariate analysis affecting non-relapse mortality(p 0.01) as well as overall survival(p 0.004). Disease status at transplantation of CR2 or PR had a lower overall survival (p 0.001) but no signifi cant impact on NRM. None of the other factors were signifi cant. Hence, age of < or >60 years and HCT-co-morbidity index of < or ≥3 can be combined to further delineate RIC allograft recipients into 3 groups; group 1(age<60years and HCT-CI 2 or less), group 2(age>60 years and HCT-CI 2 or less) and group 3 (age >60 years and HCT-CI ≥3) with 2 year NRM of 8.4%, 40% and 55% respectively (p 0.001) and O.S of 76%, 40% and 30% respectively (p 0.01).This data confi rms the effi cacy of RIC allografts in group 1 patients but shows high NRM in other two groups in whom different treatment/conditioning strategies should be considered.

cite_spans.text: Bokhari, L. Watson, E. Das-Gupta, J. Byrne, N. Russell Nottingham City Hospital (Nottingham, UK)

back_matter.text: C-reactive protein predicts outcome after reduced conditioning allogeneic stem cell transplantation M. Remberger, J. Mattsson CAST (Stockholm, SE) Purpose: The prognostic value of CRP taken before conditioning for allogeneic stem-cell transplantation was evaluated in 503 patients transplanted at Karolinska University Hospital, Huddinge. Patients: Reduced intensity conditioning (RIC) was given to 204 patients and conventional myeloablative conditioning (MAC) to 299 patients. Most patients (n=425) had a haematological malignancy while 78 patients had a non-malignant disease. An HLA-compatible related/unrelated donor was used in 196/229 cases and an HLA-A, -B or -DR mismatched donor in 78 cases.There were 287 males and 216 females with a median age of 36 years. Most patients (n=312) received PBSC while 155 were given BM and 36 CB. Results: Median level of CRP before conditioning among all patients were <10 mg/L (range <10-142). Increased CRP levels (>10 mg/L) were detected in 129 (26%) patients. Overall survival in the whole population was signifi cantly inferior in patients with increased CRP (63% vs. 53%, p<0.05). However, if analysing RIC and MAC separately, this difference only persisted among RIC patients (67% vs. 42%, p=0.004) while no difference was seen among MAC patients (61% vs. 63%, ns). Furthermore, in the RIC cohort, transplant-related-mortality (16% vs. 30%, p=0.036) and relapse-free survival (53% vs 27%, p=0.015) were worse in patients with increased CRP, while no difference in acute GVHD was seen. In multivariate analysis CRP still remained signifi cantly associated to OS (HR 1.62, CI 1.01-2.59, p<0.05), and RFS (HR 1.62, p=0.03) . No correlation between any outcome variable and CRP was seen among the MAC treated patients. Conclusion: CRP may be a good prognostic factor for outcome in allogeneic stem-cell transplantation after reduced intensity conditioning.

back_matter.text: Dose-escalated radioimmunotherapy with yttrium-90-ibritumomab tiuxetan as part of a reduced-intensity conditioning regimen for allogeneic haematopoietic cell transplantation in patients with advanced aggressive non-Hodgkin's lymphoma W.A. Bethge (1), S. von Harsdorf (2) Allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) using reduced intensity conditioning (RIC) regimens offers a potential curative therapy to patients with advanced aggressive NHL. RIC HCT induces potent graft-versus-lymphoma effects with best results in patients with low tumor burden at time of HCT. Combined use of radioimmunotherapy (RIT) with RIC may increase anti-lymphoma activity of RIC. In addition to the graft versus lymphoma effect, HCT provides rescue from hematologic toxicity of RIT which may allow dose escalation of RIT. 20 patients have been enrolled in a multicenter phase I/II dose escalation study of RIT using yttrium-90-ibritumomab tiuxetan (Y90-CD20, Zevalin) at two dose levels (0,6 (22 MBq) and 0,8 (30 MBq) mCi/kg) in 10 patients each, combined with RIC for treatment of patients with aggressive NHL. Patients received dosimetry with In111-CD20 on day -21 and RIT with an escalated dose of Y90-CD20 (0,6-0,8 mCi (22-30 MBq)/kg) on day -14 followed by RIC using fl udarabine (30 mg/m² day -8 to -4), melphalan (140 mg/ m² day -3) and alemtuzumab (20-30 mg day -3 to -2). For postgrafting immunosuppression cyclosporine was administered. Diagnoses were diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (n=13), transformed chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (n=4), blastoid mantle cell lymphoma (n=2) and follicular lymphoma grade 3 (n=1). Median age was 51 (range, 30-69) years. PBSC grafts were either from matched related (n=5) or matched unrelated donors (n=15). All patients were high risk with refractory disease or relapse after preceding autologous HCT. Disease status at time of HCT was CR=4, PR=15 and SD=1. No additional toxicity due to RIT was observed in comparison to our previous experience with the same RIC alone. Engraftment was rapid and sustained with no graft rejections. Median time to >500 granulocytes/ µL was 15 (range, 9-32) days and to >20000 platelets/µL 11 (range, 9-56) days. TRM at day +100 was 0% and overall 20%. Incidence of grade II-IV GVHD was 50% (II=8, III=1, IV=1). To date, chronic extensive GVHD occurred in 6 patients. Causes of death were relapse=6, suspected suicide=1, infection=3 and GVHD=1. 9/20 patients (45%) are alive with a median follow-up of 258 (range, 81-497) days. Disease status of patients alive is CR=7, PR=2 and Relapse=1. In conclusion, dose escalation of RIT and combined use with RIC is feasible with no additional toxicity due to RIT and with stable engraftment in all patients. Long-term disease-free survival remains to be determined.

Conditioning regimens prior to allogeneic stem cell transplantation in acute leukaemia: the role of dose intensity A. Shimoni, A. Rand, I. Hardan, N. Shem-Tov, R. Yerushalmi, A. Nagler Chaim Sheba Medical Center (Tel-Hashomer, IL) Allogeneic SCT with both myeloablative and reduced-intensity conditioning (RIC) is effective therapy in acute leukemia. To better defi ne the role of dose intensity in SCT, we retrospectively analyzed SCT outcomes in 356 consecutive adult patients (pts) with MDS/AML (n=277) and ALL (n=79) given SCT over an 8-year period in a single institution. The median age was 51 (range, 17-75) . The donors were HLA-matched siblings (n=191), matched unrelated (n=139) and alternative ( n=26). Pts meeting standard eligibility criteria were routinely given myeloablative conditioning (MAC, Cy/TBI or BuCy, n=141). Pts non-eligible for MAC were given either RIC (fl udarabine and reduced doses of busulfan or melphalan, n=116) or modifi ed myeloablative conditioning (modMAC, fl udarabine with myeloablative doses of busulfan or treosulfan, n=99). Disease status at SCT was CR1/ CR2 (n=176), previously untreated or untreated relapse (n=63) and chemo-refractory (n=117). With a median follow-up of 30 months (range 1-103), 159 pts are alive and 197 died; 75 of treatment-related causes and 122 of relapse. The estimated 5-yr overall survival (OS) in this relatively high-risk pt group was 34% (95%CI, 27-41). The status of disease at SCT was the most important factor predicting OS; 48, 31 and 16% for pts in CR, untreated or chemo-refractory leukemia, respectively (p<0.001). Multivariable analysis (MVA) identifi ed SCT not in CR, SCT from unrelated and alternative donors as adverse prognostic signs with hazard ratios (HR) of 2.7, 1.5, and 2.2, respectively. The conditioning regimen used was not a significant factor in the whole pt group with 5-yr OS of 38, 35 and 31% after MAC, modMAC and RIC, respectively (p=NS). However, RIC was associated with reduced OS in 2 subgroups. Among pts with MDS/AML given SCT not in CR, 5-yr OS was 34, 24 and 13% after MAC, modMAC and RIC, respectively (p=0.03) with HR of 1.6 for RIC in MVA. In the group of ALL pts, MVA identifi ed RIC and SCT not in CR1 as adverse prognostic signs with HR of 2.0 (p=0.04) and 2.0 (p=0.03), respectively. In conclusion, MAC should still be considered the standard of care for SCT in acute leukemia in eligible pts. RIC is associated with inferior outcome in pts with ALL and pts not in CR at SCT. Randomized studies are needed to determine the role of RIC in MDS/AML pts in CR at SCT. The novel modMAC regimens are relatively well tolerated even in pts not eligible for MAC and may be more effective than standard RIC in refractory disease.

cite_spans.text: A. Shimoni, A. Rand, I. Hardan, N. Shem-Tov, R. Yerushalmi, A. Nagler Chaim Sheba Medical Center (Tel-Hashomer, IL)

back_matter.text: Cytoreduction with clofarabine/Ara-C combined with reduced-intensity conditioning and allogeneic stem cell transplantation in patients with high-risk, relapsed, or refractory acute leukaemia S. Buchholz, J. Krauter, E. Dammann, G. Beutel, M. Stadler, M. Eder, A. Ganser Hannover Medical School (Hannover, DE) P959 Improved outcome following reducedintensity conditioning for second allogeneic stem cell transplantation D. Nachbaur, J. Auberger, J. Clausen, B. Lindner Hematology and Oncology (Innsbruck, AT) Objectives: Second conventional myeloablative allogeneic transplants for patients relapsing after a fi rst allogeneic or P962 Reduced-intensity conditioning with fl udarabine/ cyclophosphamide has remarkably high activity in relapsed or refractory lymphoid malignancies F.S. Dijkstra, O. Visser, S. Zweegman, P.C. Huijgens, J.J.W.M. Janssen Vrije Universiteit (Amsterdam, NL) Several studies suggest that non-myeloablative allogeneic stem cell transplantation (alloSCT) with reduced intensity conditioning (RIC) has encouraging effi cacy in the treatment of lymphoid malignancies. However, large series are lacking. Therefore we retrospectively analyzed data of 43 patients with indolent lymphoma (n=13), aggressive lymphoma (n=18: DLBCL n=3, MCL n=3, transformed follicular lymphoma n=10, ATLL n=1, Richters' transformation n=1) and B-CLL (n=12) receiving alloSCT after a fl udarabine/cyclophosphamide (Flu/Cy)-based conditioning regimen. Previous autologous stem cell transplants (autoSCT) had been performed in fi ve patients with indolent lymphoma and in six with aggressive lymphoma. Disease status at allotransplant was CR in 9, PR in 26, SD in 6 and chemoresistant disease in 2 patients. At a median follow-up of 653 days (range 98-2282 days) after transplantation, OS was 51.7% (95%-CI: 16.5%-86.9%), 2-yr PFS was 62% (95%-CI: 45.3%-78.8%) and 2-yr DFS was 55% (95%-CI: 36.3%-73.7%) No signifi cant differences in OS were found between the different patient groups. Overall survival according to having had a previous autologous SCT or not showed no signifi cant difference (P = 0.814). Six patients (14%) relapsed. Frequencies of grade III-IV acute and extensive chronic graft-vs-host disease were 16.3% and 51.1%, respectively. RIC with Flu/Cy therefore seems a feasible strategy in patients with lymphoid malignancies, with remarkably high activity in relapsed/refractory indolent as well as aggressive lymphoid neoplasms. Although autologous transplant(ASCT) is the election treatment in sensitive relapsed DLBCL other strategies are needed for those relapsing after ASCT or transplanted with active disease. From 1999 24 patients were included in these trials.18 (75%) had a DBLCL,3 (13%). Follicular grade 3 lymphoma, 2 (8%) a transformed MZL and 4% a BL Patients received fl udarabine 30 mg/m 2 IV ( 8 to 4) plus melfalan 70 -140 mg/m 2 (3 and 2); 12 patients (50%) enrolled in the latest trial received rituximab 375mg/m 2 ; on days -8,-1,+8 and +15 and CsA plus MTX 10mg/ m 2 (+1, +3, +6). Median age was 51 y (26-62); 4 patients (16%) were in >CR1 and 84% had active disease -10 (41%) sensitive and 10 (41%) refractory; median number of previous lines was 3 (2) (3) (4) (5) (6) (7) and 43% had received a previous ASCT. Acute GVH was 37%(8% grade III-IV). 65% of patients at risk developed cGVH, (ext 59%). At day +100 21 patients were evaluated for response: 67% responded (13 CR and 1 PR) and 7(33% progressed); in the 20 patients transplanted with active disease 11 responded (55%) (10 CR and one PR, later converted into CR), 7 didn't respond (35%) and three (12%) were not evaluable due to early death. With a mfu of 35 months (range: 4-96 months), 8 patients (33%) are alive, 7 (29%), disease free and 16 (66%) died, 8(33%) due to progression and 7 (29%) due to NRM, 2 of them in progression. Median OS is 22 mo(1-58) with a projected OS at 5 years of 30% and a plateau from 44 mo; regarding DFS, median has not been reached and estimated DFS at 5 y is 56% with a plateau phase from 10 mo. NRM at 1 year is 20%. No variables infl uenced OS or DFS although patients receiving <4 or <4 lines has an OS of 32 months and 4 months. (NS). This is one of the largest reported series of Non Myeloablative allogeneic transplant in Aggressive B Cell lymphoma; our results with this intermediate conditioning including melfalan and fl udarabine ± Rituximab indicates a good response early after transplant, however most of the patients transplanted with progressive disease do not benefi ciate from this strategy; other approaches improving conditioning as well as perhaps some kind of maintenance will be tested in the future. Also a better control of acute and chonic GVH is needed. In summary, results are encouraging with a third of the patiens showing a long term disease control suggesting a clear graft versus Lymphoma effect (GVL) in patients with B aggressive histologies.

back_matter.text: Reduced-toxicity conditioning with busulfan and fl udarabine and allogeneic stem cell transplant: chimerism evaluation and global outcome of 26 consecutive patients A. Algarotti, C. Micò, A. Salvi, C. Zanotti, A. Grassi, A. Rambaldi Ospedali Riuniti di Bergamo (Bergamo, IT) Background: Reduced intensity conditioning (RIC) regimens have been widely used to offer an allogeneic transplant to otherwise ineligible patients. Although well tolerated, RIC regimens are often associated with an increased proportion of disease relapse. We investigated a reduced toxicity conditioning regimen consisting of a myeloablative dose of Busulfan (3.2 mg/kg/day for 4 days) and Fludarabine (30mg/m² for 4 days). Patients and Methods: From January 2006 to June 2008, 26 patients with a median age of 53 years and a diagnosis of Acute Myelogenous Leukemia (AML,n=12), Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL,n=1), Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS,n=1), Multiple Myeloma (MM,n=7), Hodgkin's disease (HD, n=3) and non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma (NHL,n=2) entered this program. At the time of ASCT, 9 patients (5AML, 1ALL, 2NHL and 1HD) were in complete remission (CR), 7MM patients were all in 2nd good partial remission, 1HD patient was in partial remission while the remaining 9 patients (7AML, 1MDS and 1HD) had active disease. Results: The median dose of CD34+ and CD3+ cells infused was 4.4 x 106/kg and 202 x 106/kg, respectively. The median time to leukocyte and platelet engraftment was 16 days and 14 days respectively. At day +30, + 60 and +100 all the evaluable patients showed a full donor chimerism when BM mononuclear cells were tested. Peripheral blood CD4+ cells were of donor origin in 16/19 and 17/17 patients tested at day + 60 and +100 respectively. With a median follow-up of 370 days, 18 patients are alive (15 patients in CR, 3 with active disease) and 8 patients are dead. Fourteen patients experienced acute GVHD (grade I, n=4; grade II-IV, n=10) after a median of 47 days from ASCT. Disease relapse or progression occurred in 10 patients and was the primary cause of treatment failure. Only one patient died for a transplant-related reason (grade 4 acute GVHD). Among the 23 evaluable patients, a mild chronic GVHD was diagnosed in 7 while an extensive presentation was evident in 5 patients. Conclusion: The association of a myeloablative dose of Busulfan and Fludarabine confi rm its strong anti neoplastic activity and its remarkable tolerability in most patients who are ineligible to a full dose conditioning regimen because of age or comorbidities. Transplanted doses of T cell subsets are known to correlate with transplantation outcome. Among them, natural killer (NK) cells express anti-leukemic effect via alloreactivity and mitigate graft-versus-host disease (GVHD). However optimal dose of NK cells are not yet derived in non-myeloablative stem cell transplantation (NST). Therefore we tried to evaluate the effect of the CD56+ cell dose on NST by giving additional CD56+ cells using immunomagnetic process. Nine patients were enrolled in the protocol from January 2005 to December 2006. Transplantation outcome was compared to 7 patients who did not consent the protocol during same period. All patients had AML or ALL or high degree MDS. HLA-identical siblings or unrelated donors were mobilized using G-CSF. All patients received whole leukapheresis product on Day 1, and purifi ed CD56+ cells from second day leukapheresis were given to Day 2. Selection of CD56+ cells were performed with CliniMACS system by manufacturer's protocol. Conditioning regimens were fl udarabine plus busulphan or fl udarabine plus idarubicin plus melphalan. All patients received cyclosporine A or tacrolimus for GVHD prophylaxis. The numbers of transplanted total nuclear cells showed no signifi cant difference (supplement group; 10.95x10 8 / kg, range 9.32-18.27, non-supplement group; 10.28x10 8 /kg, range 8.25-12.45). Also transplanted doses of CD3+, 4+, 8+ cells showed no statistical difference except for CD56+ doses (106.24x10 6 /kg, range 73.59-240.95 vs. 73.02x10 6 /kg, range 46.06-112.09; P=0.04). Ratio of CD56+ cells to CD34+ cells and CD3+ cell were higher in CD56+ supplemented group. Purity of CD56+ selection was mean 96.6% (range 93.1-98.9) and yield was mean 48.3% (range 28.8-82.3). Mean period to engraftment was earlier in CD56+ group but without statistical signifi cance (mean 12.5 to 14.7 days, P=0.2). Two cases of acute GVHD(>-grade 2) occurred in CD56+ group and one case in non-supplement group. Chronic GVHD (extensive) occurred in 5 cases and 2 cases in each group. Three patients in CD56+ supplement group relapsed but soon achieved CR after salvage treatment. Two patients relapsed in control group and died of disease progression. DFS showed no difference but OS was longer in CD56+ supplemented group. Out data had limits to show benefi ts of supplementary infusion of CD56+ lymphocyte in non-myeloablative transplantation. Optimal doses of NK cells and T cell subsets needs to be determined by larger scale data. The ideal stem cell donor registry should contain a young, healthy, and motivated donor pool with ethnic diversity refl ecting that of potential transplant recipients. Many ethnicities remain under-represented in major registries, and marked genetic diversity within some ethnic groups demands a higher ratio of registrants to recipients to insure successful donor searches. The Israeli population is ethnically diverse, with large numbers of second-generation emigres from Middle-Eastern countries, Ethiopia, Baltic States, etc., prompting us to diversify the ethnic representation within our national registry. To achieve this goal, we opened a single stem cell donor recruitment site at the Israeli National Armed Forces Induction Center (Israeli law mandates on-site registration of all potential military conscripts regardless of their eventual draft status). Information about the registry and stem cell donation was provided to all conscripts, but coercion to register was not sanctioned. 70% of eligible individuals agreed to participate, with higher registration rates among potential combat conscripts vs. non-combat inductees. Since May 2005, 80392 military conscripts have entered our registry vs. 121000 individuals recruited through costly and cumbersome volunteer donor drives organized in the civilian population during the same period (current registry size 388888 donors). The median age of donors in our registry dropped from 37 years in 2005 to 32 years (as of November 2008) since we have started conscript registration. We compared requests for donor confi rmatory typing (CT) between military and civilian donors as a surrogate for the "matchability" of these donors. During this period, CT requests were received for 953 out of 308496 civilian donors and for 302 out of 80392 military conscript donors, ratios of 0.31% and 0.38% (p<0.01 by chi squared). Specifi c data on ethnic representation is difficult to obtain as many conscripts listed "Israeli" or "mixed" (parents of different ethnicities) as their ethnicity. Nonetheless, we increased the number of Ethiopian donors from nearly none to nearly 2000. The decrease in median age of our donors contributes to a longer donor dwell time within the registry. Conscripts are a highly motivated population and are generally of robust health, increasing the likelihood that they will be willing and eligible stem cells donors. The higher frequency of matching in this population refl ects its ethnic diversity.

back_matter.text: Natalizumab treatment modulates phenotypic profi le and expression of adhesion molecules in bone marrow and peripheral blood CD34+ cells of patients with multiple sclerosis U. Oelschlägel, T. Ziemsen, C. Garten, M. Markgraf, G. Ehninger, M. Bornhäuser University Hospital Dresden (Dresden, DE) Objective: The alpha 4 integrin inhibitor Natalizumab is used in the treatment of highly active multiple sclerosis (MS). Elevated CD34+ counts in peripheral blood have been described in MS patients during this treatment. In the present study CD34+ counts and expression of adhesion molecules on hematopoietic progenitor cells in bone marrow and peripheral blood of MS patients under Natalizumab (MS-BM, MS-PB) should be compared with those in healthy BM and mobilized blood after G-CSF stimulation. Methods: BM (n=11) and leucapheresis samples of (n=11) of healthy donors and BM (n=4) and PB (n=6) of MS patients were investigated fl ow cytometrically combining CD45 PerCP5.5/ CD34 APC with further antibodies in FITC and PE (CD11a, CD62-L, CD44, CD31, VLA4, CXCR4, or CD133). Measurements have been performed on a FACSCanto II. If possible, 2000 CD34+CD45dim cells with overall ca. 500,000 cells were measured. Results: Of note, the absolute CD34+ cell count was significantly higher in MS-BM compared to control samples (1334/ µl vs. 109/µl; p=0.0050). An elevated CD34+ count was also detectable in MS-PB vs. healthy steady-state PB (7/µl vs. <1/ µl). The expression of most adhesion molecules was lower in MS patients compared to healthy donors, BM: CD62-L 6% vs. 74% (p<0.05); CD11a 31% vs. 48% (p<0.05); PB: CD62-L 43% vs. 85% (p<0.01) and MFI of CD11a (p<0.05), CD31 (p<0.05), and CD44 (p<0.01). Remarkably, the CD133 expression on CD34+ cells was also clearly lower in MS-BM and PB (26% vs. 82%, p<0.01; 26% vs. 48%, p<0.01) compared to healthy donors. Repetitive measurements, done before and during 5 days after the 1st administration of Natalizumab in two patients, revealed the maximum CD34+ count between day 3 and 4. The blocking of VLA4 via Natalizumab was refl ected as a decrease in mean VLA4 fl uorescence intensity from 8157 before to 3526 at day 4. Furthermore, the expression of CD44 was also down regulated during the same time period. Conclusion: The mobilization of CD34+ cells in MS patients after Natalizumab administration in PB and even more in BM was shown to be accompanied by a down regulation of adhesion molecules. The lower CD133 expression suggests that a more mature progenitor subset is mobilized by this treatment. Further investigations should evaluate whether these differences correlate with distinct biological features and whether Natalizumab could be clinically useful as an adjuvant mobilization agent in heavily pretreated patients with hematologic diseases. The KIR genes (KIRs) and the HLA genes, located on different chromosomes, segregate independently of each other. Thus perfectly HLA-matched pairs are usually and typically mismatched for KIRs. Both activating (S-genes) and inhibitory (L-genes) KIRs probably infl uence the HSCT outcome and various studies suggest that number and/or composition of donor KIR genes repertoire may impact on transplant outcome. This suggests that number of KIRs might be the criterion of unrelated donor (UD) selection in cases with many HLA matched UD available; typically in patients with common HLA haplotypes, e.g. in the most frequent haplotype A1B8DR3 (also termed AH8.1). Methods: 41 unrelated individuals from the Czech National Marrow Donors Registry (CNMDR) with confi rmed HLA genotype A*0101-Cw*0701-B*0801-DRB1*0301-DQB1*0201 (PCR-SSP), i.e. unequivocally composed of the 2 AH 8.1 haplotypes, were genotyped for the complete set of 14 KIR genes and 2 pseudogenes. Results: 14 different KIR genotypes were found, with 9 (22%) occurred only once. The most frequent genotype found in 39% individuals corresponds to A haplotype homozygosity (AA). The remaining possessed more than 1 activating KIR and were either AB heterozygous or BB homozygous. All individuals possess inhibitory KIRs for self class I ligand (C1group) and only 4% lack either the 2DL1 or 3DL1, i.e. KIRs for not possessed inhibitory epitopes (i.e. C2 group and Bw4). Median number of all possessed KIRs was 9 (range 7-14), fi gures for S and L genes were 2 (1-6) and 7 (5-8). While AA genotypes individuals possess solely uniform 7 KIRs, AB/BB haplotypes were more heterogeneous -median of 11 KIRs (range 7-14), 13 different genotype observed. The L genes frequencies: 2DL4, 3DL1, 3DL2 and 3DL3 -100%, 2DL3-98%, 2DL1-95%, 2DL2-51%, 2DL5-37%. S gene frequencies: 2DS4-100%, 2DS2-51%, 2DS1-29%, 3DS1-27%, 2DS3-24% and 2DS5-17%. Conclusion: We confi rm the variability in terms of KIR genotypes and gene diversity even in individuals with most conserved HLA haplotype (A1B8DR8 homozygous). The selection of HLA matched UD according the KIRs contents could thus be applied in patients with common HLA phenotypes. The benefi ts of NK alloreactivity could be accomplished in such a group of patients where many perfectly HLA matched donors are usually available.

back_matter.text: Results of a prospective, monocentric study on the search of an unrelated donor for patients with high-risk acute lymphoblastic leukaemia A.P. Iori (1) Allogeneic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) is potentially curative for patients (pts) with high risk acute lymphoblastic leukemia (HRALL), and the search of an unrelated donor is a common strategy for pts lacking a family donor. To assess the effect of the search on the outcome of pts with HRALL, we analyzed prospectively 136 pts, median age 11 yrs (1-59), on search of an unrelated donor through the BMDWW Registry and Cord Blood (CB) Banks, between 1995 and 2008. At the start of the search, 37 pts were in ICR, 70 in IICR, 3 in >IICR, 26 in relapse. The cumulative incidence (CI) of fi nding a donor (CB or volunteer donor, VD) was 62% and 72% at 3 and 6 months, respectively; after this time no increase in the CI of fi nding a donor was observed. The median time from the start of the search to fi nd a donor was 1.5 months for CB and 3.5 months for VD. Fifty-one % of the 110 patients who entered into the study in CR showed a relapse at a median of 4 and 2 months from the start of the search for pts in I-II CR and >II CR, respectively. Of the 101 pts with a donor, 61% underwent a transplant: 25% in a more advanced phase compared to the start of the search; 35% of pts who started the search in relapse obtained a CR and underwent an HSCT. Therefore, 44% of pts failed to undergo a transplant because of lost eligibility due to disease progression. The 10-year probability of OS was 22.5%. Disease progression was the major cause of death. The importance of graft cell composition to outcome after allogeneic stem cell transplantation P. Svenberg, O. Ringdén, M. Uzunel Karolinska University Hospital (Stockholm, SE) Background: Stem cell dose has been shown to be important for outcome in patients who undergo stem cell transplantation (SCT). Grafts may contain varying amounts of different cell populations like CD3+, CD19+, CD56+, CD4+ and CD8+ immunocompetent cells, whose role for clinical outcome is less clear. Patients and methods: We analyzed 591 patients who underwent SCT at Karolinska University Hospital, Huddinge between 1998 to 2007 and correlated FACS results of the above mentioned cell populations to clinical outcome. Most patients (76%) had hematological malignancies. 58% of the patients received a myeloablative conditioning regimen, 62% were given peripheral blood stem cells (PBSC) and in 58% of the transplants an unrelated donor was used. Results: As expected, PBSC contained much higher levels of all different cell populations as compared to BM. We found that patients reciving high numbers of CD4+, and CD8+ cells had signifi cantly more rapid engraftment. Also, a CD4+ level above 200 x 10(6)/kg was correlated to higher risk of developing acute GVHD grades II-IV (41%) as compared to patients receiving below this level (24%) (p<0,037). While the incidence of bacteria sepsis was lower in patients receiving a high number of cell dose (CD3, CD19, CD56), no correlation between cell dose and CMV reactivation was found. Relapse free-and overall survivals were not signifi cantly affected by the different cell populations. Conclusion: Grafts containing high numbers of CD4+ cells is a risk factor for developing severe acute GVHD but survival rates were not signifi cantly correlated to graft composition. Concerns exist about underutilization and underrepresentation of ethnic minorities on donors Registries. Some ethnic groups are poorly represented within the total number of donors leading to unequal access to stem cell transplantation for all patients in need. In fact some minority groups have rare and varied HLA combinations, therefore fi nding a match is more diffi cult than among Caucasian donors. As HLA-matching requirements are less stringent, cord blood (CB) may offer to minorities with rarer and more varied HLA types an increased chance of fi nding a compatible donor. Several factors contribute to discourage minorities from participating to donors program (lack of information about: benefi ts of transplantation, existence of registries, need for donors, risk of donation and the lack of opportunity to donate). Common barriers to donation can be addressed by educational strategies aimed at increasing knowledge and educating minorities about the importance to people of their ethnic background of becoming a donor, as a match is more likely within the same ethnic group. For this reason, a project of minority recruitment was initiated by our CB Bank in 2006 with the goal of increasing the number and genetic diversity of CB units available for matches. Initiatives included brochures and promotional materials that were distributed to donation centres at free costs. Education materials and informed consent were translated into fi ve languages (English, French, Spanish, Arab, Albanian) and carry complete information about the donation procedure and purpose. Here we evaluate the impact of such a strategy on implementing the ethnic diversity among our CB Bank. As a result of this programme (see the graphic), between 2006 and 2008, the number of non-Italians donors increased as referring to those coming from Europe but remained stable for those coming from extra-European countries. The proportional distribution of racial and ethnic groups among the CB collections is far away from approaching their proportional distribution in population. Further efforts are required to increase not only understanding of the need of CB donations for minority donors but also their motivation and opportunity to donate by establishing relationships with community centres in collaboration with bilingual translators and cultural mediators. Background: Data regarding the characteristics of graft cells products obtained by healthy infants are lacking. Objective: To compare the graft products obtained by infants with that obtained by young matched HLA-identical sibling donors for thalassemic recipients. Methods: Consecutive healthy infant donors(<24 months of age) and 99 young donors (3-53 years, median 15,1 years) undergoing bone marrow stem cells collection for their matched recipients entered the study. Main variables of interests analyzed were donor weight, patient weight and the ratio donor weight/patient weight in order to identifi ed great unfavourable differences between donors and recipients weights (ratio <1). Levels of CD34 cells and CD3 cells collected in the bone marrow donations were assessed and compared between the two study groups. Results: The weight of infant donors was signifi cantly less then the young donors (median 10.9 vs 43.5 Kg, p<0.001) and consequently the bone marrow volumes harvest were significantly smaller (median 258 ml vs 630 ml (p<0.001). Indeed we observed that the median weight recipient is rather two-fold greater then the respective infant donors (18,8 kg patients vs 10,9 kg donors) on the contrary in the young donor group the patient weight exceeds not much the half of the donor weights (26,8 kg patient vs 43,6 kg donors). In order to quantifi ed the unfavourable discrepancy between donor and recipients Allogenic haematopoietic stem cell transplantation (alloHSCT) is a well-established treatment for several haematological malignancies. However, little is known regarding the real costs of this procedure in our setting. The aim of this study is to determine the total costs of alloHSCT in patients with haematological malignancies. Forty-three peripheral blood alloHSCT recipients were included in this analysis. We reviewed all clinical activity and categorized it by in-patient admission, out-patient visits, diagnostic procedures, laboratory tests, and medication use (divided by conditioning regimen drugs, antifungal prophylaxis and treatment drugs, and all other pharmacy expenditure). All costs were analysed for an initial period up to day +100 after alloHSCT. Unit costs for drugs were obtained from the hospital pharmacy and for all other resources from the Soikos database. All costs are expressed in Euros 2008. Transplant donor costs were not taken into account at this point. Patients in the study had a median age 52 (20-68), 58% were male, 30 had an MDS-AML, 6 a lymphoid malignancy, 4 CML, 3 ALL. Eighteen received a myeloablative conditioning and 25 a reduced intensity conditioning, 31 from a related and 12 from an unrelated donor. Median time to neutrophil engraftment was 17 days (13-33), and incidence of acute graft versus host disease grades II-IV was 30.2%. Patient overall survival at day +100 was 79%. Mean total cost per patient was €46,010. Hospitalization costs accounted for the majority of these (€21,727, 47% per patient), followed by drug costs (€14,210, 31% per patient) and diagnostic and laboratory tests costs (€10,072, 22% per patient). Mean conditioning treatment costs per patient were €1,882 (4%, €4,464 myeloablative conditioning costs -MAC-and €521 reduce intensity conditioning -RIC-), mean baseline disease drug costs per patient were €4,602 (10%) and mean fungal prophylaxis or treatment drug costs per patient were €7,727 (17%). Up to a 60% of all costs were incurred in the fi rst 30 days from hospitalization for alloSCT. Non pharmacological treatment costs accounted for 69% of all costs, mainly due to hospitalization costs (47%). Allogenic stem cell transplant poses a high burden on the patient and society, with total costs around €46,000 per patient for the fi rst 100 days.

back_matter.text: Objective: Interleukin-7 (IL-7) is essential for T cell development in the thymus and maintenance of peripheral T cells. The alpha-chain of the IL-7R is polymorphic with the existence of 4 SNPs (+510C/T (rs1494558), +1237 A/G (rs1494555), 2087T/ C (rs6897932) and +3110A/G (rs3194051), that all give rise to amino acid substitutions. We previously found an association between donor +1237G and increased treatment related mortality (TRM) and acute graft versus host disease (aGvHD) after matched unrelated donor (MUD) hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) as well as allergy. The C allele of +2087 has been associated with allergy and multiple sclerosis. The aim of the present study was to evaluate the prognostic signifi cance of IL-7Ra SNP genotypes in a large cohort of adults receiving MUD HCT for haematological malignancies. Patients and methods: 590 Caucasian adult (>18 years old) patients with AML (n=111), ALL (n=76), CML (n=373) or MDS (n=30) in early stage disease receiving a myeloablative conditioning regimen and an allele-level matched (HLA-A, B, C, DRB1 and DQB1) T cell replete HCT from an unrelated Caucasian donor from the National Marrow Donor Program. IL-7Ra polymorphisms were determined by an SSP-PCR system in genomic DNA extracted from banked pre-transplant blood samples from the NMDP Research Repository. Univariate and multivariate analyses were performed for overall (OS), transplant-related mortality (TRM), relapse, and acute grades II-IV and III-IV and chronic GvHD, adjusting for clinical variables in the multivariate analysis. Results: Neither donor nor recipient SNP genotypes were signifi cantly associated with overall survival or TRM. Associations between donor SNP genotypes, relapse and GvHD are summarized in the table. Conclusion: Although the univariate analysis indicated an impact of the previously identifi ed risk alleles of SNP +2087 (C) and +1237 (G) of the donor on GvHD or relapse, this was not confi rmed in the multivariate analysis. Our study does not fi nd suffi cient evidence to support an association between the three examined IL-7Ra SNPs and adverse outcomes in MUD HCTs. (1) (

Müller (1) (1)National University Hospital (Copenhagen, DK); (2)Center for International Blood and Marrow Transplant Research (Minneapolis, US); (3)National Marrow Donor Program (Minneapolis, US); (4)Medical College of Wisconsin (Milwaukee, US); (5)Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center (Seattle, US)

back_matter.text: Background: We report the results of a multicenter prospective randomized study analyzing the impact of darbepoetin alfa with or without i.v. iron on erythroid recovery after autologous HCT. Patients and Methods: 127 autologous HCT recipients with lymphoid malignancies were randomized 1:2:2 between no treatment (group 1, n=25), darbepoetin alfa (Aranesp®) 300 µg QOW starting on day 28 after HCT for a total of 7 doses (group 2, n=52), or the same regimen of darbepoetin alfa plus i.v. iron sucrose (Venofer®) 200 mg on days 28, 42 and 56 after HCT (group 3, n=50). Primary endpoints included proportion of complete correctors (i.e. patients reaching Hb ≥ 13 g/dL) before day 126 post-transplant and median time to achieve Hb correction in each arm. Results: In intent to treat analyses, the proportion of complete correctors was 24% in group 1, 81% in group 2 (P<0.001 compared with group 1), and 92% in group 3 (P<0.001 compared to group 1, and P=0.099 compared to group 2). Median time to achieve Hb ≥ 13 g/dL was not reached in group 1, 42 days in group 2 (P<0.001 compared to group 1), and 32 days in group 3 (P<0.001 compared to group 1 and P=0.127 compared to group 2). Mean ± standard deviation total doses of darbepoetin-alfa administered were 1,445 ± 489 µg in group 2 vs 1,272 ± 443 µg in group 3 (P=0.06). Eight patients (2 in group 1, 4 in group 2, and 2 in group 3) required red blood cell transfusions on study, including 4 patients following early disease progression. In per protocol analyses, the proportion of complete correctors was 21% in group 1, 80% in group 2 (P<0.001 compared with group 1), and 96% in group 3 (P<0.001 compared to group 1, and P=0.029 compared to group 2). Median time to achieve Hb ≥ 13 g/dL was 190 days in group 1, 44 days in group 2 (P<0.001 compared to group 1), and 31 days in group 3 (P<0.001 compared to group 1 and P=0.025 compared to group 2). There was no difference in ferritin levels, nor in rates of thrombo-embolic events, or other complications among the groups. Conclusions: This is the fi rst prospective randomized trial demonstrating that darbepoetin alfa is safe and highly effective to ensure full erythroid reconstitution after autologous HCT when started on day 28 posttransplant. I.v. iron sucrose tended (not statistically signifi cant in intent to treat analyses) to further fasten erythroid recovery with a lower dose of darbepoetin alfa required.

back_matter.text: The aim of this phase II randomized trial, was to demonstrate the non-inferiority of one fi xed dose pegfi lgrastim (PEG) compared to daily fi lgrastim (FIL), in patients receiving high-dose chemotherapy (HDC) and peripheral stem cell support (PBSC). Patients and methods. From September 2006 to March 2008, 80 patients with hematological malignancies and solid tumors were enrolled in this phase II open-label randomized study. Conditioning regimens were different based on disease and preference of each center. Autologous PBSC were reinfused at day 0. PEG was administered subcutaneously at fi xed dose (6 mg) 24h after autologous stem cell infusion (day +1). FIL was administered subcutaneously at weight-based daily dose (5 mcg/kg/d) from day +1. The primary end points were duration of severe neutropenia (absolute neutrophil count, ANC < 0.5 x 10 9 /L) and the number of days to achieve an ANC > 0.5 x 10 9 /L starting from the days +1. Secondary end points were the number of days to achieve an ANC > 1.0 x 10 9 /L starting from the days +1, number of days with fever > 38 °C, duration of antibiotic therapy, and number of documented infections. Results. Patient and disease characteristics were reported in Table  1 . No differences were observed between the two groups (FIL vs PEG). The duration of ANC less than 0.5 x 10 9 /L and the time to reach an ANC more than 0.5 x 10 9 /L were not signifi cantly different (mean days 6 vs 6, and 11 vs 11, p value: 0.5, respectively). No statistically signifi cant differences were observed in terms of mean time to reach an ANC more than 1.0 x 10 9 /L (12 vs 12 days), number of patients with fever (24 vs 22), number of documented infections (12 vs 10), mean number of days with fever (1.7 vs 0.97 days), duration of antibiotic therapy (5.7 vs 3.5 days). Finally, no differences were documented regarding extra-hematological toxicities and time to discharge between the two groups (16 vs 14). Time to reach a platelets count more than 20 x 10 9 /L was signifi cantly shorter in PEG group compared to FIL group (15 days vs 11 days, p value 0.054). Considering the average wholesale price, and the mean number of vials (20) used in FIL group, the use of PEG reduced the per patient cost of 562 euros. Conclusions. This phase II randomized study shows that PEG was not inferior to FIL in terms of hematological reconstitution (primary end point). Consequently, PEG could be safely used after PBSC infusion.

back_matter.text: The G-CSF effect in the setting of splenomegaly and extramedullary haemopoiesis: a mobilisation study in a thalassaemia mouse model as compared to normal strain E. Yannaki, N. Psatha, E. Athanasiou, G. Karponi, D. Bougiouklis, V. Constantinou, M. Demertzi, P. Kaloyannidis, I. Batsis, A. Anagnostopoulos, A. Fassas George Papanicolaou Hospital (Thessaloniki, GR) A G-CSF-associated risk of splenic rupture has been recognized in normal donors of hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs). Limited information is available on the G-CSF effect in the presence of splenomegaly and extramedullary hemopoiesis as in thalassemia. Gene therapy (GT) has recently been postulated as a therapeutic potential for thalassemia and the mobilized autologous CD34+ cells may represent the preferable source of stem cells for genetic modifi cation due to the higher yield of HSCs compared to bone marrow harvest. An enlarged spleen may potentially pool HSCs from the periphery and negatively affect mobilization. We explored the G-CSF effect in a thalassemic mouse model (HBBth-3) as compared to a normal strain (C57Bl6), in terms of safety, mobilization effi cacy and distribution of HSCs among hematopoietic compartments. There was no death or clinical sequelae of splenic rupture in G-CSF-treated animals of either strain, however, at the time of sacrifi ce, hemorrhagic infarcts were detected only in the spleens of G-CSF-treated HBBth-3 mice (5/40). In contrast, the G-CSF effect on spleen size was stronger in the normal than in the thalassemic (thal) strain (133% vs 65% increase of the spleen volume over baseline). HBBth-3mice mobilized less effectively than C57Bl6 mice (Lin-sca-1+ckit+ cells/microl PBM-NCs:90±55 vs 255±174, p=0.01/CFU-GM/ml PBMNCs:390±262 vs 1131±875, p=0.01) due to increased trapping of HSC and progenitor cells into the spleen (Lin-sca-1+ckit+cells/spleen: 487±35 vs 109±19.6, p=0.01/CFU-GM/spleen/102:1470±347 vs 530±425, p=0.0006). Splenectomy restored the mobilization profi ciency of thal mice at comparable levels to normal mice (Lin-sca-1+ckit+ cells/microl PBMNCs:164±111 vs 223±99, p=ns) and resulted in the development of a hematopoietic compensatory mechanism in the steady-state liver of splenectomized thal mice which was greatly increased after G-CSF. G-CSF didn't signifi cantly affect Hb or reticulocytes in either strain when spleens were intact. However, G-CSF caused anemia after splenectomy in the C57 but not in the thal mice due to intense compensatory liver hemopoiesis. Our data imply that, in view of human GT for thalassemia, either multiple cycles of mobilization or alternative ways (ie AMD3100+G-CSF), may be required for a suffi cient yield of transplantable gene-modifi ed HSCs in non-splenectomized patients. Strategies also to reduce the risk of G-CSF-induced splenic infarcts should be explored in a clinical setting.

cite_spans.text: E. Yannaki, N. Psatha, E. Athanasiou, G. Karponi, D. Bougiouklis, V. Constantinou, M. Demertzi, P. Kaloyannidis, I. Batsis, A. Anagnostopoulos, A. Fassas George Papanicolaou Hospital (Thessaloniki, GR)

back_matter.text: We have previously reported that the presence of A at position 801 in the 3'-untranslated region (3'-UTR) within the stromal cellderived factor -1 (SDF-1/CXCL12) gene was associated with a higher yield of CD34+ mobilized for haematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) in autologous patients and allogeneic donors. Initial work also showed the strong correlation between S301 the A+ allel and HSC accommodation in marrow, refl ected by the granulocytes recovery (expressed as the day post transplant when the number of granulocytes exceeded 500/ul) in the group patients after autologous HSCT. These studies prompted us to analyse the infl uence of the SDF-1 gene polymorphism on the granulocytopoiesis (>500/ul) and megakaryopoiesis (platelet count > 20x10 3 /ul) in patients undergoing autologous and allogeneic HSCT. In total 162 recipients (40 auto and 122 alloHSCT) and 122 allogeneic donors were genotyped for SDF-1 alleles using a PCR-RFLP technique and digestion with MspI restriction enzyme. Number of transplanted CD34+ cells was associated with the pace of granulocytes and platelets recovery in autologous (R Spearman: -0.380; p<0.016 and -0.468, p<0.003 for granulocytes and platelets, respectively) and allogeneic (-0.369; p<0.0001 and -0.0357, p<0.0001) transplant recipients. Autologous transplant recipients carrying the SDF-1A allele characterised with faster recovery of granulocytes (median: 15 vs 17 day after HSCT, p<0.032) and platelets (median: 17 vs 21 day after HSCT, p=0.033). The multiple regression analyses (considering: patients' age and sex, number of transplanted CD34+ cells and SDF-1 polymorphism) confi rmed the independent association of the SDF-1-A allele and number of CD34+ cells in the graft (p=0.032) with granulocyte (p=0.049 and p=0.032) and platelet (p=0.027 and p=0.019) recovery after autoHSCT. In allogeneic transplant recipients, all AA+ carriers and only 72% of those having G allele (p=0.037) were among patients that recovered in granulocytes prior to 19 day post alloHSCT independently of number of transplanted CD34+ cells.In conclusion, the presence of the SDF-1-A allele facilitates the mobilization of CD34+ cells from bone marrow to peripheral circulation and (in addition to the number of CD34+ transplanted cells) also signifi cantly infl uences the hematological recovery of granulocytes and platelets in patients after HSCT. Supported the MNiSW grants No. N-N401-008035 and N-N402-193335. Granulocyte colony-stimulating factors (G-CSF) alone or in combination with CHT are standard procedures for mobilization of peripheral blood stem cells (PBSC). Recently the pegylated form of G-CSF has been introduced, that leads to a larger molecule with an increased half-life. While pegfi lgrastim is equivalent to daily fi lgrastim in enhancing neutrophil recovery, its effi cacy in PBSC collection is still under evaluation. From January 2006 to October 2008 37 patients (pts) with malignant lymphoma were eligible for stem cell mobilization and ASCT. They were relapsed or progressive disease or mantle-cell, T-cell lymphoma at diagnosis. Pts received DHAP-modifi ed schedule (ESHAP) as cytoreductive and mobilizing regimen. Twenty-four hours after the chemotherapy they received a dose of 6 mg of pegfi lgrastim. For the characteristics of pts see Table 1 . Peripheral CD34+ cell evaluation started from the increase of WBC above 1x10 9 /L. PBSC were collected using a Cobe Spectra separator. Leukapheresis started when the number of circulating CD34+ cells was >7microL and performed daily until target number of PBSC ≥2x10 6 was reached. All pts were considered for time to neutrophil and CD34+ cells recovery, as for the engrafment after high dose CHT. Thirty-fi ve pts (94%) performed successfully PBSC collection, that was completed after a single apheresis in 33 pts. The median time to a suffi cient number of CD34+ was 10 days (8-12 days). Two pts required an additional procedure, despite the satisfactory number of CD34+ circulating. At the time of harvest the median peak of absolute CD34+ cells in the PBL was 68 microL (range 7-252) and the median CD34+ cells collected for single patient were 9,4 x10 6 /Kg (range 2,4-47,6) . No failure at collection was recorded and 28 pts obtained an optimal harvest (>5,0x10 6 /Kg). Up to now 23 pts evaluable for engrafment after BEAM regimen engrafted. The median time of grade 4 neutropenia was 8 days (range 6-10 days) and the recovery of platelet ≥20 x10 9 /L was recorded in median 12 days after the reinfusion (range 8-21 days). Our experience showed that a single injection of pegfi lgrastim in combination with CHT is a valid procedure for mobilization of CD34+ cells into the PBL in pts with malignant lymphoma. Besides, a high percentage of pts (82%) obtained an optimal collection just with a single leukapheresis. Finally, the pegfi lgrastim-mobilized CD34+ cells induced rapid and sustained engrafment after myeloablative CHT.

Gieryng (1), K. Bogunia-Kubik (1), S. Madej (2), M. Mordak-Domagala (2), A. Lange (3) (1)Institute of Immunology and Experimental Therapy, PAS (Wroclaw, PL); (2)Lower Silesian Center for Cellular Transplantation & National Polish Bone Marrow Donor Registry (Wroclaw, PL); (3)Institute of Immunology and Experimental Therapy & Lower Silesian Center for Cellular Transplantatio (Wroclaw, PL)

back_matter.text: Timing of G-CSF injection for effective autologous stem cell collection J.E. Kim, C.-W. Suh, E.K. Kim, B.S. Sohn, I. Park, D.H. Yoon, C. Yoo, G. Jang, D.H. Lee, S.-W. Kim, J.S. Lee Asan Medical Center (Seoul, KR) Results: Co-expression of multiple KIRs on NK cells was more frequent than expected from random association of independent events. Individuals having three or four of the major KIR ligands had similar frequencies of NK cells expressing multiple KIRs as those with only one KIR ligand. The distribution of self and nonself-KIRs at the cell surface refl ected a stochastic combination of receptors rather than a selection process conferred by cognate HLA class I molecules. Co-expression of KIR and NKG2A differed for individual KIRs but was independent on the presence of cognate HLA class I ligands. Together, these results indicate that KIR expression is independent of expression of cognate HLA class I ligands in the host and regulated by a stochastic process characterized by increasing expression probabilities during KIR acquisition. Conclusion: The results provide new insights into the formation of the KIR repertoire and argue against selection of human NK cells conferred by HLA class I molecules. Better knowledge on how inhibitory KIR repertoires are formed in new hematopoietic environments may have implications for how to interpret and exploit NK cell mediated alloreactivity in allogeneic stem cell transplantation. (1) Objectives: Transplantation over HLA barriers involving killer cell Ig-like receptor (KIR)-HLA mismatch may trigger donor NK cell alloreactivity that contributes to graft-versus-leukemia effects and improved survival of patients with myeloid malignancies. Such effects have also been reported in HLA-matched stem cell transplantation (SCT) when donor NK cells express KIR for non-self HLA ligands. This is intriguing and indicates that mechanisms of NK cell tolerance and hyporesponsiveness may be set-aside during the post-transplantation period. Methods and results: To explore this possibility, we have performed a retrospective analysis of the outcome in a cohort of 110 patients with acute myeloid leukemia (n=82) and myelodysplastic syndrome (n=28), undergoing T cell-replete SCT with an HLA-matched sibling donor. Lack of ligands for donor inhibitory KIR had no effect on overall survival, incidence of relapse or graft-versus-host disease. Presence or absence of activating KIR genes in donors with KIR haplotype group B and A respectively, had no effect on outcome, nor did any specifi c activating KIR-HLA combination. In line with these clinical observations, functional analysis of the NK cell repertoire post SCT using multicolour fl owcytometry revealed maintained hyporesponsiveness of NK cells expressing inhibitory KIRs for non-self HLA ligands. Conclusions: Our results provide evidence against the emergence of an alloreactive NK cell repertoire in HLA-identical allogeneic SCT.
