back_matter.text: Cord blood banking: the role of NIMA haplotypes on searching for stem cell compatible donors C. Capittini (1) , P. Bergamaschi (2) , A.M. Pasi (2) , C. Badulli (2) , I. Sbarsi (2) , F. Garlaschelli (2) , M. Guarene (2) , A. Marchesi (2) , B. Romano (2) , V. Genovese (2) , M. Martinetti (2) , L. Salvaneschi (2) , M. Cuccia (1) (1)University of Pavia (Pavia, IT); (2)IRCCS Policlinico San Matteo (Pavia, IT) The search of compatible donors still represents the major limit to widespread use of allogeneic stem cell transplantation (ASCT). Haploidentical siblings may provide an alternative transplant option when HLA-matched related donors are not available, the disadvantages being essentially the increased risk for graft-versus-host disease (GvHD) and graft rejection. In particular, ASCT from an inherited paternal HLA antigen (IPA)/ non inherited maternal antigen (NIMA)-mismatched donor has been previously demonstrated to be feasible decreasing GvHD and preserving graft-versus-leukaemia (GvL) effect. In fact, maternal cells passing the placenta during pregnancy express HLA molecules which are acknowledged by the foetus, who develops a tolerance to NIMAs maintained in adulthood. In the setting of unrelated ASCT, the maternal haplotypes are easily available for cord blood (CB) units while this information is not provided for adult donors. As NIMAs should be tolerated by the CB immune system, one can argue that the knowledge of the donor's NIMA haplotype (a third ghost haplotype) could further augment the chance for fi nding a compatible CB donor and reduce immune complications of ASCT. For this purpose we fi rst identifi ed the 9 most frequent NIMAs and inherited maternal alleles (IMAs) in the Cord Blood Bank of Pavia, aiming to establish if the NIMA haplotypes could be a common source of genotypic compatibility in our population. In our policy, low and high resolution DNA analysis was used to defi ne HLA-A, HLA-B and HLA-DRB1 alleles for each CB-mother couple participating to the CB banking program. Typing was performed by PCR-SSP and PCR-SSO. 6324 haplotypes for the HLA-A, HLA-B and HLA-DRB1 loci were considered retrospectively, corresponding to 1581 CB units and their mothers. The frequencies of HLA-A; -B;-DRB1 haplotypes were obtained by direct counting. 7 haplotypes out of the 9 most frequent were present both as NIMAs and IMAs, as shown in the graphic. In our population NIMAs appear to be neither rare genotypic combinations nor preferentially non-inherited haplotypes. Thus, the knowledge of the real tolerogenic potential of CB units, namely the third haplotype that is the NIMA one, may further increment the immunological privileges of this stem cell source, in particular for patients affected with non-malignant diseases for whom GvL effect is not relevant, while reduced GvHD is highly desirable.

The effect of donor KIR and patient HLA genotypes on outcome following allogeneic haematopoietic stem cell transplantation in a Chinese population H. Huang (1) Killer cell immunoglobulin-like receptors (KIRs) are a family of inhibitory and activatory receptors and expressed by most NK cells. It is reported that KIR-ligand mismatch can alleviate aGVHD, reduce relapse and improve disease-free survival in mismatched allo-HSCT. However, the role of KIRs on outcomes of allo-HSCT remains controversial. The aim of this study is S304 to investigate the infl uence of KIR-ligand mismatch and some activatory receptors of donor KIR on the outcome in Chinese population. Methods: KIR genes were typed by using PCR-SSP, and HLA-A, B, and C loci genes were used by PCR-SSP or PCR-SSO. These patients received standard myeloablative (n=180) or nonmyeloablative (n=23) conditioning followed by stem cell transplantation from HLA matched (n=164) Conclusion: KIR-HLA mismatch can contribute to improved outcomes of patients with myeloid malignancy. Donor having activatory gene whether KIR2DS2 or KIR2DS5 was associated with lower aGVHD. The presence of KIR2DS2 gene in the donor was also associated with a lower risk of mortality following allo-HSCT, resulting mainly from a decreased incidence of grade II-IV aGVHD.

Both naïve and memory lymphocyte subsets participate in alloresponses to HLA mismatched stimulatorsimplications for selective depletion of GVHD reactivity J. Barrett, M. Smith, Z. McIver, N. Hensel, J. Melenhorst National Institutes of Health (Bethesda, US) Since lymphocytes do not normally encounter cells from unrelated individuals, it is presumed that alloresponses causing GVHD are mainly derived from naïve T cells. However, memory cells may also participate in the alloresponse, following sensitization through pregnancy, or through cross-reactivity, against viral antigens. We used fl ow cytometry to track alloresponding T cell activation using CD38, and proliferation by CFSE dilution. Umbilical cord mononuclear cells (UCMC) from fi ve donors were stimulated with an irradiated pool of HLA-disparate donor peripheral blood mononuclear cells (alloPBMC). By day 8, over 80% of the cells were CD38+CFSE dim, indicating naïve T cells were alloresponsive. Next, PBMC from adult donors were negatively immunomagnetically sorted into subsets, using CD57+ and CD45RO+ for naïve (N) cells, CD45RA+ and CD57+ for central memory (CM) cells, CD62L and CD57+ for effector-memory (EM) cells, and CD27+ and CD45RO+ for effector (E) cells. Adult N, CM and EM cells -and to a lesser extent, E cells -proliferated and acquired CD38 expression comparably to naïve T cells, indicating that all subsets can be alloresponsive. Electronically sorted T cell subsets, stimulated with single donor alloPBMC confi rmed that CM + EM CD4+ and CD8+ T cells make proliferative alloresponses. PBMC subsets from 3 adults were then primed for 8 days with alloPBMC and tested for intracellular cytokine (IFNg; TNFa; IL-2) production after rechallenge with the pool. CD4+ and CD8+ N, CM + EM cells (but predominantly CM cells) generated cytokines after exposure to alloPBMC. While showing a proliferative response to stimulus with PBMC, UCMC only produced cytokines when rechallenged with CD3+ antigen presenting cells (with high costimulatory molecule expression) but not the original PBMC. These data confi rm that not only naïve T cells from neonates and adults, but also adult memory T cells respond to alloPBMC. To directly assess if T cells specifi c for DNA viruses such as EBV cross-react with alloantigens, we stimulated PBMC from three adults with EBV lysates and immunomagnetically sorted CD137+ cells. Cells expanded for three weeks were rechallenged with EBV-negative alloPBMC. We found a small but signifi cant population of bi-reactive T cells producing IFNg or TNFa. These fi ndings indicate that in man alloresponses are not confi ned to a particular subsets of post-thymic T cells, and that strategies to prevent GVHD by naïve T cell depletion may be ineffective.

back_matter.text: Management of platelets transfusions in highly immunised beta thalassaemia children undergoing bone marrow transplantation S. Napolitano, E. Zino, R. Chiesa, B. Cappelli, R. Crocchiolo, E. Biral, A. Noè, I. Frugnoli, T. Roccia, C. Evangelio, M. Fossati, A. Polselli, L. Barzizza, S. Rossini, F. Ciceri, P. Ronchi, M.G. Roncarolo, K. Fleischhauer, S. Marktel Scientifi c Institute H S Raffaele (Milan, IT) Between 2005 and 2008, 47 thalassemia patients from middle east countries received a Bu-Cy based myeloablative BMT in our unit. During the aplasia post BMT, we experienced a high incidence of refractoriness to platelets (plt) transfusions (trx). This is explained by the presence of anti HLA antibodies (abs) in patients transfused in countries using non leukodepleted blood units. Based on this, we set up a system (HLA specifi c trx) to identify the best plt donor by avoiding HLA antigens against which the patient had specifi c anti-HLA-abs. Patient characteristics: median age 8 years (range 2-17), 22 in Pesaro transplant risk class II, 25 in class III. Median number (MN) of blood trx pre BMT for class , class III: 101 (6-230). Plt refractoriness to trx defi ned as corrected count increment < 4,5 at 24 h post trx calculated as body surface*(post plt trx-pre plt trx)/number plt in transfused unit. All patients in class III were positive for anti HLA antibodies (MN 26, range: 9-54), whereas only 16/22 in class II (MN 18, . Trx of random plt to immunized patients resulted in 74% refractoriness compared to 25% in non immunized (p< 0.0001). Among immunized patients, splenectomized patients had a better plt trx outcome to random units (p < 0.01). In addition, patients with more then 26 anti-HLA-abs had a higher number of failed plt trx (82%) compared to patients with < 26 abs (64%), p< 0.01. When HLA specifi c trx were employed (in immunized patients only), 68% trx were successful, compared to 26% with random trx (p < 0.0001). When a plt donor negative for antigens against which the patient had specifi c abs was not identifi ed, 1 antigen mismatch was tolerated. Analysing trx outcome depending on the degree of HLA match and AB0 compatibility, we documented that full HLA match is probably better then 1 antigen mismatch (p=0.08) and that AB0 compatible units are probably better then incompatible (p < 0.4) and the best result is obtained when HLA matched and AB0 compatible plt were used (p< 0.07).

back_matter.text: In conclusion, we documented a high incidence of anti-HLA-Abs in middle east thalassemia patients. In this setting, the use of HLA specifi c trx following BMT resulted in improved transfusion outcome, limitation of costs, fl uid overload and exposure to multiple donors. We suggest that this method is more effective and worth cost wise. HLA-DR15 is associated with autoimmune bone marrow failure syndromes such as aplastic anemia, and in this setting predicts response to immunosuppressive treatment. A particular susceptibility of DR15 expressing hematopoietic cells to autoimmune attack has therefore been suggested. We hypothesized that DR15 may also play a role in allo-immune effects after allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT). In a datafi le of 7521 10/10 matched unrelated donor transplants contributed to the International Histocompatibility Working Group (IHWG) in Hematopoietic Cell Transplantation (HCT) we investigated rates of survival, disease relapse and acute GvHD in patients with or without DR15. Transplants facilitated by the Japan Marrow Donor Programme (JMDP, n=2569) were analyzed separately from non-JMDP (n=4952) transplants due to differences in the frequencies of the DR*1501 and 1502 alleles. DR15 was present in 46% of JMDP and 34% of non-JMDP transplants. Effects were analyzed for DR15, as well as for its most frequent alleles, DR*1501 (more prevalent in non-JMDP patients) and DR*1502 (more prevalent in JMDP patients). DR15+ and DR15-patients were well matched for disease stage, age at transplant, rates of T-cell depletion, matching of HLA-DP, and donor/recipient gender. No statistically signifi cant effects of the presence of DR15 were observed for survival, rates of relapse, incidence and severity of acute GvHD, with the exception of a small reduction in rates of grade II-IV aGvHD in DR15+ patients of borderline statistical signifi cance (hazard ratio 0.89, 95% confi dence interval 0.79-0.99, p=0.03, see Figure 1 with univariate survival and cumulative incidence curves and Table 1 with adjusted hazard ratios). In conclusion, in a large population of well-matched unrelated donor transplants, the presence of HLA-DR15 did not impact survival, risk of disease relapse, or acute GvHD incidence and severity. These data suggest that DR15 does not appear to confer a special susceptibility to allo-immune effects in the setting of matched unrelated donor allogeneic HSCT.

Soluble CD30 following allogeneic haematopoietic stem cell transplantation: an immunologic marker for an immunologic reaction? K. Hübel, B. Cremer, E. Heuser, M. Hallek, H.P. Hansen University of Cologne (Cologne, DE) CD30, a member of the TNF receptor family, is preferentially expressed by activated or memory Th2 cells, regulatory T cells and NK cells but not by resting B cells or T cells. In the transplant setting, CD30 plays an important role for the balance between Th1/Th2 immune responses, modulating immune responses and tolerance induction. CD30 is cleaved by metalloproteinases and the ectodomain, soluble CD30 (sCD30), is released. In organ transplantation (heart, liver, kidney) several investigators documented the relevance of sCD30 in the peripheral blood as a predictive marker for allograft rejection. In fact, patients with high levels of sCD30 had a reduced graft survival. Considering these results, a signifi cant role of sCD30 also in hematopoietic stem cell transplantation could be assumed. In our project we investigate sCD30 levels at different time points (day -1, day of engraftment, day 30, day 100, and in case of graft-versus-host-disease (GvHD) development) in patients undergoing allogeneic stem cell transplantation. The primary goal of this trial is the evaluation of possible correlations between sCD30 levels and immunologic reactions defi ned as GvHD or graft-versus-leukaemia effect. At this time, a total of 10 patients have been observed until day 100 (AML: 4 pts; ALL: 2 pts; CML: 2 pts; CLL: 1 pt; T-NHL: 1 pt). Several fi ndings emerge from this investigation: 1.) In all patients, levels of sCD30 at baseline (day -1) were low (mean 24,9 U ± 9,44 U (SEM). 2.) There were 4 patients with no signs of GvHD until day 100. In these patients, no signifi cant changes in sCD30 levels were found. 3.) Mild to moderate GvHD which responded well to therapy did not show increased sCD30 levels. 4.) Two patients experienced high sCD30 levels. One patient developed severe lethal GvHD (CD30, min: 10 U; max: 134 U); the other patient had continuous moderate GvHD (CD30, min: 60 U; max: 145 U). 5.) One patient with mild GvHD showed elevated sCD30 levels in the relapse situation (CD30, min 10 U; max 70 U). In conclusion, these results suggest a critical role of sCD30 as predictive marker for immunologic reactions after allogeneic stem cell transplantation.

cite_spans.text: K. Hübel, B. Cremer, E. Heuser, M. Hallek, H.P. Hansen University of Cologne (Cologne, DE)
